content.description: #3 Eliminate the hold for your hands on the problem to the right, left hand undercling, fire up right hand to small crimp, grab left handed Gaston 4 inches to the left of the small crimp, these are the Two Holds I believe, Â Dyno straight up to the rail off of the two holds

From the parking lot walk back and angle slightly right. Stay to the right side of the first line of boulders you reach. Pass the first two faces- The Lichen boulder is about 20 ft. high and maybe 30-40 ft. long with a nice flat landing area and a horizontal crack system about 12 ft. up. This is lichen traverse. It's a good endurance problem on big holds, just past vertical. Usually started from the diagonal crack on the far right.

climbs.name: Lichen It A Bit More Traverse

content.description: Lichen traverse with a finish over the arch on the far left side. It's a good endurance problem on big holds, just past vertical. Usually started from the diagonal crack on the far right. Also good starting on the far left. It's given V2 in one guide, but seems a little easier than that.
content.protection: Pad or no pad, it's a little ways up but a flat, soft landing.
content.location: From the parking lot walk back and angle slightly right. Stay to the right side of the first line of boulders you reach. Pass the first two faces- The Lichen boulder is about 20 ft. high and maybe 30-40 ft. long with a nice flat landing area and a horizontal crack system about 12 ft. up.

content.description: #7 this one starts right in the center of the wall, goes up and to the left

Overhung granite boulder wedged between 2 other boulders. Start seated on the lower end of the wedged boulder and work up the boulder to the top out.

All other boulders are out of bounds.
content.protection: Bring a boulder pad or just fall softly, it's a pretty safe fall if you get your feet under you.
content.location: From the parking lot take the trail farthest to the east (right) until you see a sort of sideways rock wedeged between a couple of other rocks on your left. If you go around a corner and see a vertical boulder with a slabby top you've gone too far.
